A Fresh Start for Giving

Kids Who Count's Interactive Redesign

Kids Who Count is a local non-profit charity offering services for children, such as early intervention, mental health, and vision/screening support. The charity’s mission is to support child development and empower families by providing necessary resources allowing children to reach their unique individual potential. The original site was challenging to navigate and lacked visual and functional appeal. I aimed to create a site that supports parents and families through visual and functional elements.

Discovery

I began the redesign process with a site audit of the original site to determine what the problems were. Pain points include navigation, visual appeal, and layout. I then looked at other non-profits for inspiration and best practices, this inspired a mood board. I decided on a potential color scheme that portrayed feelings of happiness, friendliness, and genuineness. I also added examples of other sites I liked—colors, layout, or overall feeling. The mood board lays out my initial ideas while providing continual inspiration and sparking ideas.

Content Creation

In the next step, I took general and incomplete ideas and began to form them into complete thoughts. I decided on font and font sizes, color and gradients, and potential buttons, navigation, forms, icons, and logos. This created my pattern library to help guide my next couple of steps.

Wireframes

Low-fidelity wireframes are created next and used to establish layout, structure, and organization. No colors or pictures are used to keep it simple and straightforward. I was able to take all of the inspiration, ideas, and content I had received and make it multiple complete pages. I received feedback from my peers in order to continue to improve and develop my wireframes.

Surface Compositions

Once I edited and reedited my wireframes, I began to add color and pictures, and redesigned any elements that looked out of place. Surface comps are one of the final stages and display what my site will actually look like. After I finished each page, I created a high-fidelity, clickable prototype. I could see how my pages are connected, linked to one another, and active navigation. This was the final and most satisfying stage of the Kids Who Count redesign.

What I Would Do Differently

  • Usability Testing: Conduct user studies that would determine what parents and caregivers needed most
  • Increase Engagement Features: Add donation tracking elements, testimonials, or sucess stories
  • Enhance Readability: Refine my visual design and add more contrast

Conclusion

Although my charity redesign was not used, I learned from the experience and process of redesigning a site. Practicing and working through each step helped me gain crucial skills and insight I would not otherwise have. I refined navigation and created a visually appealing site that is happy, uplifting, and welcoming.
